Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: Several users report intermittent errors that disrupt normal usage
Story: I was sitting at my desk, eyes glued to the error logs on my screen, when my phone buzzed. It was a message from Mom: “Can you call when you have a minute? Dad seems a bit down today.” I glanced at the clock—already past 7 p.m. The QA team had just flagged a critical bug, and users were complaining about random crashes. My manager’s last email was clear: “We need a fix tonight.” I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. My parents rarely reached out for emotional support, and I knew how much it meant to them when I checked in. But the code wasn’t going to fix itself, and the team was counting on me. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, torn between dialing home and diving back into the code, my heart pounding with the impossible choice.
